item.title: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the skilled trades: Canada Emergency Response Benefit
item.description: This article, coauthored with Sophia Su, is published on Statistics Canada’s Education, learning and training: Research Paper Series. French version is also available. (Below is the introduction of the article and subject to Statistics Canada Open License Agreement.) Since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, several unprecedented government interventions related to COVID-19 ‚Äî including the closure of non-essential businesses, travel restrictions and public health measures limiting public interactions ‚Äî have been put in place.

item.title: Labour market outcomes of journeypersons designated as visible minorities
item.description: This article, coauthored with Sophia Su, is published on Statistics Canada’s Education, learning and training: Research Paper Series. French version is also available. (Below is the summary section of the article and subject to Statistics Canada Open License Agreement.) Using data from Statistics Canada‚Äôs Education and Labour Market Longitudinal Platform (ELMLP), this study examines populations designated as visible minorities in the skilled trades. The labour market outcomes, one year after certification, of journeypersons designated as visible minorities, who responded to the 2016 Census of Population and received certificates in the skilled trades between 2008 and 2017, were compared with the outcomes of journeypersons who are not visible minorities.

item.title: Canadian Apprenticeship Longitudinal Indicators: Interactive Tool
item.description: We - together with my colleagues Chaoyang and Anouk - created this interactive data visulization tool based on Shiny. Check out at Statistics Canada‚Äôs website: English version La version fran√ßaise All programs are available on this GitHub repository.

item.title: Shiny app: Interprovincial mobility of journeypersons in Canada
item.description: I made this interactive visualization tool based on Shiny. It presents the data (Statistics Canada Table 37-10-0204-01) in a nice Chord diagram. Please not that this is not an official product from StatCan. English version La version fran√ßaise All programs are available on this GitHub repository. Update on June 24, 2021 This product is going to be discontinued. The above link may not be maintained and can be removed in the future.

item.title: Canadian Apprenticeship Registrations and Certifications: Interactive Tool
item.description: This is a Power BI-based data visualization tool I made. Check out at Statistics Canada’s website: English version La version fran√ßaise Many teams at StatCan publish a lot of interesting interative tools, which appear not very well-known.

item.title: Factors associated with the completion of apprenticeship training in Canada
item.description: This article is published on Statistics Canada’s Insights on Canadian Society. The Daily (a short summary of the article for press release): Study: Completing apprenticeship training in Canada Article: Factors associated with the completion of apprenticeship training in Canada Infographic: Completing apprenticeship training in Canada French versions are also available: Le Quotidien, L’article, L’inforgraphie (Below is the abstract of the article and subject to Statistics Canada Open License Agreement.

item.title: Essays on Family Economics
item.description: This is my doctoral dissertation, which took so much longer time than I planned. The copy is available through Western University library. This thesis studies decisions the family makes regarding household unions, fertility, and child investment. Chapter 2 studies the educational gradient in non-marital fertility and posits that cohabitation is a driver behind the gradient. I build a lifecycle model of fertility and household union choices, featuring a trade-off between quality and quantity of children.

item.title: My Name
item.description: My name is Hyeongsuk Jin. Hyeongsuk is my given name, and Jin is my family name. It’s a Korean name and is written as ÏßÑÌòïÏÑù1 in Korean characters. I know that many people who don’t speak Korean find my first name - Hyeongsuk - hard to read.2 It’s a name with two syllables - in the way syllables are counted in the Korean language, ‘Hyeong Ìòï’ and ‘suk ÏÑù’. The first syllable, ‘Hyeong,’ sounds similar to the English word ‘young,’ but with the sound of ‘h’ in front of it, or a strong initial sound.

item.title: Usual Disclaimer
item.description: All contents in this blog are my own, and none of them are reviewed, supported, or endorsed in any manner by my employer(s). Any opinions or ideas expressed in the contents are strictly my own, and they do not represent my employer’s, any groups' or organizations' I belong to.

item.title: about
item.description: Hi, I’m Hyeongsuk. üëã You can read a little bit more about my name in this post. I’m working as an analyst at Statistics Canada. At work, I study issues related to the registered apprenticeship programs in Canada. I’m also working on some data visualization projects. I studied economics at Western University (aka the University of Western Ontario). In my doctoral dissertation, I studied decisions the family makes regarding household unions, fertility, and child investment.
